I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has conducted an annual orientation program for the 
government officials of its developing member countries (DMCs) since 1989, except in 1996.1 The 
program has provided the participants with carefully designed in-house training involving (i) exposure 
to ADB’s policies, procedures, and operations; (ii) introduction to selected aspects of development 
planning; (iii) discussion of project management skills; and (iv) awareness of ADB’s changing role. 
The  participants  were  generally  midlevel  government  officials  with  experience  in  managing 
development work. This technical assistance (TA) will meet the costs of continuing the program for 
the 3 years from 2004 to 2006.2 The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The program provides an opportunity for participants to enhance their familiarity with ADB 
policies and procedures, and ADB’s activities in their countries. Furthermore, it aims to help the 
participants upgrade their skills, particularly in development planning, and managing development 
activities in their countries. The program also promotes networking opportunities and good will 
between ADB and participating DMCs. From ADB’s perspective, the program serves as an important 
public  relations  opportunity  to  enhance  ADB’s  visibility  and  development  impact  within  the 
participating DMCs.  A total of 291 participants from 35 DMCs have benefited from the Program 
(Appendix 2 presents the distribution of participants by year and country). 
 
3.  Other ADB programs are available for officials of DMCs and staff of executing agencies, to 
impart skills in specific areas like economic assessment, project management, and procurement. 
The scope, coverage, and duration of such programs are different from that of the program proposed 
in this report. 
 
4.  Since 1997, Participants in the program have been surveyed regarding the program’s merits. 
They noted that the concept is fundamentally sound, and they returned to their countries with a 
better understanding of ADB’s operations and policies. They also interacted closely with ADB staff 
who  are  working  with  their  countries.  A  parallel  and  useful  outcome  of  the  program  is  that 
participants learned about other countries and cultures; an experience that is of value particularly to 
participants engaged in regional economic cooperation activities.  Since 2003, an alumni scheme 
has been established to keep the program participants of previous years updated on major changes 
and developments in ADB’s policies, procedures, and operations.  
 
5.  The  survey  of  previous  participants  also  suggested  some  areas  for  improvement.  To 
maximize the understanding of the participants, the presentations will be more interactive (e.g., 
break-out group discussions) and more opportunities will be available for the participants to meet 
with ADB staff. To assure that the program is tailored to the needs of the participants, the needs is 
the  participants  assessed  1  month  in  advance  of  the  program  each  year  and  the  program  is 
designed incorporating such identified needs as appropriate.  
 
 
 
 
                                                 
1 The title Orientation Program replaced the title Special Secondment Scheme, which was used from 1990 to 1995. 
2 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet edition) on 9 January 2004.

2 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
6.  The objectives of the 2004–2006 program are to 
 
(i)  increase  familiarity  of  counterpart  officials  with  ADB’s  policies,  procedures,  and 
operations; 
 
(ii)  improve participants’ knowledge of planning, managing, monitoring, and evaluating 
development activities; 
 
(iii)  enhance the relationship between ADB and the DMC counterpart agencies; and 
 
(iv)  enhance the DMCs’ understanding of ADB’s changing role. 
 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The  program,  which  will  be  held  annually  over  the  3  years  2004–2006,  will  support 
approximately 35 participants each year from selected DMCs for 2.5 weeks at ADB headquarters. 
Participants will be from organizations in DMCs that borrow from ADB and/or are counterparts to 
ADB in implementing ADB-financed projects and programs. Each of the selected DMCs will be 
invited to send one official for the program. The nominees should be government officials at the level 
of director or deputy director of a division (or equivalent), preferably from planning agencies, the 
ministry of finance, the ministry of economic affairs, or other central ministries associated with ADB 
operations in the DMC concerned. All participants must have a working knowledge of English. ADB’s 
resident  missions  and/or  counterpart  agencies  in  DMCs  may  recommend  suitable  government 
and/or ministry officials as participants for the program. 
 
8.  Based on the success of the previous programs and the lessons learned from them, the 
current program will have a variety of learning opportunities taking into consideration the needs of 
the participants and the accommodative capacity of the ADB departments and offices. Aside from 
the participants’ surveys, other measures to evaluate achievement of the program’s objectives will 
include surveys of and views from resident mission staff 6 months after the training and a follow-up 
survey  and/or  questionnaire  to  the  participant’s  supervisor  to  ascertain  the  change  in  the 
participant’s performance.  
 
9.  Briefing sessions of the program will include (i) introduction to ADB’s strategies, policies, and 
procedures; (ii) ADB’s loan products and project processing operations; (iii) procurement operations; 
(iv) consulting services; (v) disbursement operations; (vi) economic and financial analysis of projects; 
(vii) project performance monitoring and lessons learned from post evaluation of projects; and (viii) 
visits to an international organization and ADB project sites. ADB’s accountability mechanism and 
anticorruption policy will also be adequately covered in the program. Another important topic will be 
ADB’s role in subregional and regional cooperation among DMCs. In this regard, it is important to 
show how ADB is changing its own profile of lending instruments and focus on knowledge transfer in 
projects and TAs.

3 
10.  The sessions will include several case studies dealing with such issues as procurement, 
consultant selection, and disbursement, and will be based on ADB’s day-to-day experiences. The 
Strategy and Policy Department and the Regional and Sustainable Development Department will be 
closely consulted in defining the program content.  
 
11.  In addition to the regular sessions, the participants can visit counterpart divisions to discuss 
project-related or other issues of interest to deepen their understanding of ADB’s operations. The 
Human Resources Division (BPHR) will arrange the meetings in cooperation with the divisions 
concerned. 
 
12.  To increase the learning impact, the participants will be encouraged to become involved in 
the program before it starts. Issues of interest in ADB’s operations and the expectations of the 
participants  will  be  incorporated  into  the  course  content,  design,  and  delivery.  Operations 
departments  are  expected  to  provide  information  about  the  latest  policy  developments  to 
participants.  This will allow the participants to prepare for sessions that are more interactive than in 
the past.  
 
13.  During  the  program,  ADB  will  organize  study  tours  so  that  participants  can  visit  other 
international organizations operating in the Philippines, such as the International Rice Research 
Institute, and ADB-financed projects being implemented in the Philippines. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $725,000 (Appendix 3). The TA will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  TA  funding  program  and  will  provide  round-trip  airfare  (economy  class), 
accommodation, and per diem for each participant. The participating DMC governments will grant 
leave of absence to their participants in the orientation program and continue to pay their salaries 
during that period. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.   ADB  is  the  Executing Agency  for  the  TA  and  will  recruit  an  individual  as international 
consultant for 7 person-weeks for each orientation program. The consultant must be knowledgeable 
about ADB’s set up, policies, procedures, and operations, and will be responsible for arranging the 
briefing sessions in coordination with the departments and offices concerned, preparing the case 
studies, and arranging the details of the participants’ assignments with their counterpart divisions. 
Outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  attached  as  Appendix  4.  The  international 
consultant  will  be  selected  and  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants. Secretarial services and logistical arrangements will be provided by an individual locally 
recruited consultant (seminar assistant) who will be engaged for 15 person-weeks in accordance 
with ADB’s guidelines and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic 
consultants.  
 
16.  The Orientation Program will be conducted during October and/or November each year. 
ADB,  through  BPHR,  will  administer  the  TA  in  close  consultation  with  concerned  operational 
departments and offices within ADB. Participants will be selected by BPHR in close consultation with 
the  counterpart  divisions  mainly  in  operations  departments.  The  estimated  completion  date  is 
December 2006.

4 
17.  At the end of each annual program, participants will evaluate the usefulness of the program, 
and the logistical and administrative arrangements. Their feedback will help ADB and resource 
speakers improve the program to better meet participant’s needs in the following year. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the provision 
of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $725,000 on a grant basis for the 2004–2006 
Orientation Program for Officials of the Asian Development Bank’s Developing Member Countries, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.     International Consultant 
 
1.  An international consultant will prepare and implement the Orientation Program for officials 
of the developing member countries of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). The tasks will take 
7 person-weeks for each annual orientation program. The consultant must be familiar with 
ADB’s  set-up  and  its  policies  and  procedures,  and  should  have  previous  experience  in 
organizing training activities and/or seminar or workshops. 
 
2.  The work of the consultant will include, but will not necessarily be limited to, briefing 
sessions, case studies, assignment plans, field trips, and administrative arrangements for the 
program. 
 
3.  Briefing Sessions. The consultant will organize and implement briefing sessions on all 
relevant topics including the following: 
 
(i)  introduction to ADB’s policies and procedures, 
(ii)  ADB’s loan products, 
(iii)  project processing procedures, 
(iv)  procurement operations, 
(v)  consulting services,  
(vi)  disbursement operations, and 
(vii)  managing for results at ADB  
 
4.  The consultant will schedule the lectures and the briefing sessions and identify suitable 
resource  speakers/presenters.  Supported  by  the  Human  Resources  Division  (BPHR),  the 
consultant will also be responsible for the administrative arrangement of the sessions. 
 
5.  Case  Studies.  In  consultation  with  the  departments  and/or  offices  concerned,  the 
consultant will prepare case studies on ADB’s work experience. These case studies will give 
participants an opportunity to become actively involved in the learning process and to obtain 
hands-on  experience  with  ADB’s  daily  work.  The  consultant  will  evaluate  the  participants’ 
recommendations and discuss potential solutions with them. 
 
6.  Assignment Plans. In consultation with the counterpart divisions of ADB, the consultant 
will prepare the plans for the assignment of the participants to the divisions. 
 
7.  Field Trip. The consultant will identify international organizations in the Philippines whose 
operations can be studied by the participants, and arrange a 1 day study tour to one such 
organization.  The  consultant  will  evaluate  the  participants’  recommendations  and  discuss 
potential solutions with them. 
 
8.  Administrative Arrangements. In cooperation with Human Resources Division (BPHR) 
staff,  the  consultant  will  make  the  administrative  arrangements  necessary  during  the 
assignment period of the participants. In particular, the consultant will prepare materials to brief 
former program participants on recent ADB developments.

10  Appendix 4 
 
 
 
B.  Domestic Consultant 
 
 
9.  The  seminar-workshop  assistant,  who  will  be  a  locally  recruited  consultant,  will  be 
primarily responsible for the administrative arrangements from about 3 months prior to and 1 
week after the 2004–2006 Orientation Program for DMC Officials. 
 
10.  The  assistant  must  be  familiar  with  ADB's  policies  and  procedures  and  should have 
previous experience in organizing training activities. 
 
11.   The work of the assistant will include, but not necessarily be limited to, the following tasks. 
In  consultation  with  the  Human  Resource  Specialist  who  is  the  overall  coordinator  of  the 
program and in cooperation with the foreign consultant, the assistant will be responsible for 
coordinating briefing sessions and for other administrative arrangements for participants during 
the entire duration of the program.  These tasks include receiving incoming participants; lodging 
and payment of their per diem, assigning participants to divisions, arranging travel and visas, 
organizing the workshop venue and orientation proper, coordinating and organizing local tours 
for the participants, monitoring budget, posting the program activities in ADB web site and 
intranet, and arranging any other activities necessary for the success of the program. The 
assistant will also prepare a master list of participants, both current and in earlier programs, so 
that they can be contacted again by ADB and briefed on recent developments. As part of the 
Alumni Scheme, the assistant should maintain and/or update, and have the alumni directory 
uploaded in the intranet, ensure circulation to all the program participants, and provide the 
Office of External Relations (OER) with the updated list for circulation in the ADB Review.
